Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

The management and staff of the San Leandro Milk Plant are committed to operating the Plant with
the highest regard for the safety of the public, Plant personnel, and the environment. To ensure the
safety of the public, Plant personnel, and the environment, the Plant has implemented a
management system that integrates the elements of OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM)
standard, 29 CFR 1910.119 and EPA's Risk Management Program (RMP) rule, 40 CCFR Part 68.
The policies and procedures integrated under the Plant's management system specifically address
prevention of the release of anhydrous ammonia, and emergency response to an accidental release
of ammonia.

Description of Processes, and Regulated Substances Handled at the San Leandro Milk Plant

The San Leandro Milk Plant produces fluid milk and other products that require refrigeration.
Anhydrous ammonia is used as a refrigerant in the mechanical compression refrigeration system at
the San Leandro Milk Plant. Ammonia is handled in a closed-loop process that consists of the
following general stages: Liquid storage; Expansion; Evaporation; Compression; and Condensation.
Mechanical refrigeration is a physical process, rather than a chemical process: the ammonia
undergoes no chemical changes in the refrigeration cycle. Heat is removed from the product being
refrigerated or frozen as ammonia changes phase from liquid to vapor. By reliquefying the ammonia
vapor, the ammonia can be used continuously in the refrigeration cycle.

The ammonia refrigeration system is the only process at the San Leandro Milk Plant, which is
subject to the EPA RMP rule (and the OSHA PSM standard, and the CalARP program). Anhydrous
ammonia is the only regulated substance handled in the ammonia refrigeration system.

At ambient temperature and pressure, ammonia is a colorless gas with a characteristic, irritating
odor. Ammonia is highly soluble in water.

Ammonia is the third highest-volume chemical produced
in the United States. The chemical formula of ammonia is NH3. Anhydrous ammonia is handled
both as a pressurized liquid at ambient temperature and as a refrigerated liquid within the San
Leandro Milk Plant refrigeration system.

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

The San Leandro Milk Plant facility has an Emergency Action Plan in effect. The Emergency Action
Plan (Plan) is detailed in the Emergency Planning and Response section of the PSM/RMP
document, which is maintained at the facility and updated as necessary. This Plan was designed to
meet the following objectives:

1.) To save lives.
2.) To minimize and avoid injuries.
3.) To protect the environment.
4.) To minimize property damage.

The San Leandro Milk Plant maintains a safety committee whose members are the designated
emergency coordinators for the facility. The Plan provides the response organization and
notification procedures, evacuation routes, ammonia health hazards, and mitigation procedures
which will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the
facility. This Plan is reviewed and updated at least once per year. This Plan was reviewed and
updated to ensure compliance with the PSM and RMP regulations, as well as to incorporate facility
changes.

The San Leandro Milk Plant has coordinated emergency response efforts with the local fire
department and with the contracted refrigeration operation and maintenance firm. In the case of an
ammonia-related emergency, it is the policy of San Leandro Milk Plant to evacuate and to allow the
fire department and the refrigeration contractors to respond to the emergency. The Fire Department
will notify the public in the event of a release, and indicate the need to evacuate, shelter in place, or
take other actions as appropriate.

Accidental Release Prevention Program

The San Leandro Milk Plant ammonia refrigeration system has many safety features. Much of the
safety of the system is inherent in the policies and procedures that govern the operation of the
system. For example, the San Leandro Milk Plant facility operates in accordance with OSHA's
Process Safety Management regulation.

The San Leandro Milk Plant facility including the ammonia system was designed and constructed in
accordance with the Uniform Mechanical Code which specifically outlines requirem

ents for the safe
operation of the ammonia refrigeration system. These safety features include an "Emergency Pressure Control System" to automatically relieve excess pressure in the High Pressure Receiver to the Pump Trap. All pressure vessels are equipped with pressure relief valves that relieve to discharge headers plumbed to an ammonia diffusion tank located outside.

In addition to the Uniform Mechanical Code, the facility will operate in accordance with the
International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration (IIAR) guidelines. In particular, the IIAR Bulletin
110, "Startup, Inspection, and Maintenance of Ammonia Refrigeration Systems."

Five-year Accident History

EPA's RMP Program defines "accident" as the following:

"The release must be from a covered process and involve a regulated substance held above its
threshold quantity in the process.

The release must have caused at least one of the following:
On-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage (§68.42(a)); or
Known offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering
in place (§68.42(a))."

A review of the facility's accident history revealed that there have been no significant releases of
ammonia that exceeded the Federal Reportable Quantity of 100 pounds in the last five years
(August 2013 - August 2018). In addition, there have been no releases of ammonia that meet the
RMP definition of "accident" as described above.

Emergency Response Program

The San Leandro Milk Plant has an Emergency Action Plan (plan) in effect at the facility. This Plan
is detailed in the PSM/RMP document maintained at the facility. The Plan was designed to meet the
following objectives:

1.) To save lives.
2.) To minimize and avoid injuries.
3.) To protect the environment.
4.) To minimize property damage.

San Leandro Milk Plant maintains a safety committee whose members are the designated
emergency coordinators for the facility. The Plan provide

s the response organization and
notification procedures, evacuation routes, ammonia health hazards, and mitigation procedures
which will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility. This Plan is reviewed and updated at least once per year. This Plan was reviewed and
updated to ensure compliance with the PSM and RMP regulations.

In the event of an ammonia release, supervisors or ranking engineers will initiate plant evacuations.
If a supervisor is unavailable, any employee can initiate a plant evacuation by activating the Internal
Alarm System, by dialing "86" and leaving the telephone off the hook. Personnel will attempt to shut
off equipment if possible, and proceed to the meeting place upwind of the facility by observing the
windsock on top of the Raw Milk Tank (RT-5). The primary meeting place is at the Truck Repair
Shop, in the southwest corner of the property. The secondary meeting place is the front parking lot
between the office and Raw Milk Receiving Bays. A supervisor or ranking engineer will conduct a
headcount to be sure everyone is accounted for utilizing the daily employee schedules, sign in book,
and on site contractor list.

Ammonia is a strongly alkaline substance that can result in irritation or damage to skin, eyes, and
mucous membranes. Liquid ammonia can also cause freeze burns to unprotected skin. In the event
that an employee is injured on the job, the Senior Person in Charge will be notified to determine the
necessary course of action. If the injury is life threatening, 911 will be called immediately. If an
employee is exposed to ammonia enough that it has caused burning and irritation, the area of
exposure will be flushed with cool water for 15 minutes or longer. Employees will not attempt to
remove clothing from a victim with ammonia frost.

San Leandro Milk Plant has coordinated emergency response efforts with the local fire department
(Alameda County Fire Department,

925-833-3473) and with the contracted refrigeration operation
and maintenance firm. In the case of an ammonia-related emergency, it is the policy of San Leandro
Milk Plant to evacuate and to allow the fire department and the refrigeration contractors to respond
to the emergency. The Fire Department will notify the public in the event of a release, and indicate
the need to evacuate, shelter in place, or take other actions as appropriate. The Plant Engineer or
Maintenance supervisor is responsible for notification of necessary agencies. All employees at San
Leandro Milk Plant will be given emergency response training during New Employee Orientation and
Department Safety Meetings. At least annual emergency evacuation drills are held at the facility.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

The PSM/RMP prevention program elements have been integrated into the San Leandro Milk Plant's
management system framework, in accordance with internationally recognized principles of total
quality management. The management system is designed to ensure implementation of each
program element, in compliance with the OSHA PSM standard, and the EPA RMP rule. Authority,
responsibility, and accountability are clearly and specifically assigned to Plant management,
supervision, and staff. The means of documenting compliance have been improved for each
prevention program element.
